page.title:
CEC Experience with Peak Load Reduction
CEC Experience with Peak Load Reduction
page.enlisting:
In 2000 and 2001, the California legislature allocated to the Energy Commission funds for peak load reduction programs The Energy Commission offered grants, loans and rebates. Specifically, $ 21 million for “enhanced automation” Due to problems with electricity supply in California during 2000 and 2001, these programs were designed and implemented in a very fast manner before any dynamic tariffs were provided (e.g. CPP, RTP) The next two slides provide a summary of program results during 2001
In 2000 and 2001, the California legislature allocated to the Energy
Commission funds for peak load reduction programs
The Energy Commission offered grants, loans and rebates.
Specifically, $ 21 million for “enhanced automation”
Due to problems with electricity supply in California during 2000 and
2001, these programs were designed and implemented in a very fast
manner before any dynamic tariffs were provided (e.g. CPP, RTP)
The next two slides provide a summary of program results during 2001

page.title:
TOU Pricing vs. Dynamic Pricing (CPP & RTP)
TOU Pricing vs. Dynamic Pricing (CPP & RTP) T O U
P r i c i n g
v s .
D y n a m i c
P r i c i n g
( C P P
&
R T P )
page.enlisting:
Time-of-Use (TOU) is typically 3 time blocks published in advance for entire season – Peak, Shoulder, Off-Peak – Cannot address unforeseen weather or equipment failures Critical Peak Pricing (CPP) is a high price imposed on a few days a year when energy is expensive or system conditions are critical or near critical – Non-CPP hours are less expensive as a result – Customer pays the critical price when invoked by the utility • day-ahead forecast of CPP offers added time for response Real-Time Pricing (RTP) is the hourly marginal cost of a kWh – Reflects hot weather, scarcity, or equipment failure • day-ahead forecast of RTP offers added time for response Time-of-Use (TOU) is typically 3 time blocks published in advance for entire season – Peak, Shoulder, Off-Peak – Cannot address unforeseen weather or equipment failures Critical Peak Pricing (CPP) is a high price imposed on a few days a year when energy is expensive or system conditions are critical or near critical

page.title:
CEC/CPUC Vision: Dynamic Prices & Choice
CEC/CPUC Vision: Dynamic Prices & Choice
page.enlisting:
Always TOU or Better if digital meters available and if economic “CPP” is an extension of TOU Residential and Small Commercial – Default = CPP – Hedge = TOU Intermediate Size Customers (perhaps 200 kw to 1 MW) – Default = CPP – Hedge = TOU – Option = RTP (voluntary) Large (perhaps > 1 MW) – Default = RTP – Hedges to CPP or perhaps TOU Goal of an additional 1% of Load Response per year
Always TOU or Better if digital meters available and if economic
“CPP” is an extension of TOU
Residential and Small Commercial
– Default = CPP
– Hedge = TOU
Intermediate Size Customers (perhaps 200 kw to 1 MW)
– Default = CPP
– Hedge = TOU
– Option = RTP (voluntary)
Large (perhaps > 1 MW)
– Default = RTP
– Hedges to CPP or perhaps TOU
Goal of an additional 1% of Load Response per year
